in the muscles, which, as a whole,
must softly withdraw into the face or nicely disappear,
plump of flesh, with folds and dimples in the hands, as in children.
Now we should consider the children:
They are five heads tall, but smaller accordingly;
three heads to the genitals,
to the thighs and calves, two.

15. You will encounter different proportions in life:
short of length, and slim.
Children are (as Pliny tells us)
grown to half their height in three years.
Now, young painters, accept these few things.
I shall instruct you further in how to place a figure
so that it does not waver, and how to make it act and move,

ab.b: CHAPTER IV: Pose, balance, and the proper execution of a figure.

div.ab:
1. Heaven, being kind and bountiful,
has granted noble Nature,
along with other essential gifts,
the virtue of beauty, moral and artistic,
which is utterly pleasing to the eye.
If we examine the origin and means,
we discover in the circumstances why
Nature’s beauty is perfect beauty.
left-middleNature is beautiful, because of the various virtues or gifts she possesses.

2. It can be clearly discerned
in the many manifestations of natural things
that beauty is disfigured and diminished
when secondary failures occur,
which will lead us to our intended subject:
how sometimes we painters, despite working diligently,
cannot make a figure that satisfies us,
yet without understanding why.
left-middleBeauty is diminished when any subsidiary elements are missing.
left-middleSometimes young painters make a figure that displeases them, without knowing what is deficient; therefore, the following instructions.

3. While the contours of our figures reveal enough relief,
sometimes the forceful movement
of a pose fails, or the Figure leans
as if about to fall, or it has a peculiar,
unstable quality. In order to avoid
these things in the future, which are so wrong,
it is necessary for instruction to be given.
